title: What is the difference between dipole-dipole and dipole induced dipole forces? - Quora

response.answer_text: Consider HCl molecule is polar molecule and acts as dipole because Cl keep attracted shared electron hence partial -ve charge on Cl and partial +ve charge on H atom .. In Such these polarised HCl molecules, H+ of a molecule attracts e clouds of Cl- of other HCl molecules .. Other case where HCl gas it put with Non polar Cl2 gas (Cl-Cl) . If H+ of polarised HCl is near any Cl of Cl2, H+ attracts e from that particular Cl because having e deficient, then that particular Cl again attracts e from other bonded Cl and becomes partially -ve .. Thus polarity induced in nonpolar Cl2 because of polar HCl, this phenomenon is induced dipole .. (Cl---Cl) ( H+—Cl-) => (Cl+—Cl-) (H+—Cl-) Polarity generated on non polar Cl2 is induced dipole here ..
